review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review 

PLEASE NOTE (2017): Due to recent false accusations of plagarism, I (the reviewer) would like to stress that all these reviews and upcoming reviews are original and are not blatantly copied. Other reviews are used to help stress my point across but are changed in such a way to make the review in my own wording [/h1]

Super Trench Attack 2 is a game developed and published by Retro Army Limited and is the sequel to Super Trench Attack!

It is an open world goofy action and adventure game. The game plays as an isometric game rather than overhead like seen in traditional RPG games and there are also these cool first person shooting gallery type stages that are a lot of fun

The controls do take a minute to getting used to but after a while you get used to them

I have played both Super Trench Attack! and also Super Trench Attack 2 and I gotta say that there is huge differences between the first game and the second game and although I found the sequel to be confusing at first, it's not a bad game to play for a couple of hours

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

review:
Pros- Cheap. Good for a laugh before the novelty wears off.

Cons - Everything once the novelty wears off in about 20 minutes.

Basic plot of the game, ripped directly from FTL. 
So, you have the "GET ITEM,  BASE ENTIRE GAME ON RUNNING FROM ENEMY, THEN FOR THE FINAL LEVEL, YOU TURN AROUND AND FIGHT AFTER GEARING UP FOR RUNNING THE ENTIRE GAME".

It was not fun then, it's not fun now. In fact, it's even more annoying. I did not like that part about FTL.  If you didn't read a guide or were playing blind, it's suddenly a massive fight at the end of the game. A game you spent the majority avoiding combat, building up your crew and not wasting time. Now you're up against THE STRONGEST ENEMY IN THE GAME because apparently , none of the other ships that are vastly superior to yours can do a damn thing about it.
But upon knowing this information, FTL's difficulty of getting through sectors in one piece suddenly vanishes when you know that all your speed is worthless and you need massive firepower for the final fight.

But this isn't about FTL, this is about STA2.

Excessive overabundance of Negative Events - Then the onslaught of negative events is impressive, even for this type of game.  Even FTL had sectors that were positive event locations. This? Using the Investigate Option most of the time leads you to take an unruly amount of damage. I could count in my previous games the amount of times I actually managed to "SNEAK PAST" but " x decided to , Fart, Whistle, Stepped on a Twig, Forget to Sneak" gets tired after a while.

Length - Did they really have to make it as long as an FTL run? 

Lack of actual control over the game - Lack of ability to actually deploy your units in your own formation, so every battle is a LOL SUPRISE!  - HAH HAH HAH HAHA. SO FUN AND CHALLENGING. MY WEAKEST UNIT SURROUNDED BY MACHINEGUNNERS AND DOGS ON A LEVEL WITH NO SHOP, GUESS HE GETS WOUNDED UNTIL THE NEXT AREA. 

What I don't understand is why is it random anyway? In the instances you actually do manage to ambush an enemy or choose to enter combat willings, which is rare enough ; Shouldn't you be able to choose where your people are positioned? Not go into battle and find your mortar unit surrounded by Scouts, halfway across the map where no help can each him in time.

Because any of the LOL RANDUM xD healing events either heal for the lowest amount possible or backfire in extreme ways.

Speaking of which.

Inability to heal properly - Wow. The game is designed to be as annoying as possible. Between Hunting Spots not spawning, the Useless Insane Magican never working and sectors without shops period, food being unable to heal the wounded severely cripples you if you say used investigate and lost massive amounts of health or got into a fight where all your useful units were on the wrong side of the map while your weaker ones were polishing enemy guns with their hair.

then there;'s combat in general.

The game loves to deploy either your best unit as far away as possible or your weakest unit either right next to a unit that will slaughter them if they attempt to move OR surrounded by dogs and or snipers and the rest of the units are just far enough that they won't make it in three actions.
 
Having this happen once or twice, sure but when it's 80% of the game. Not fun.

Another issue with combat is that some of the time, enemies not facing your character can fire an interception shot at them. Again, once or twice , it's a fluke, when it happens the majority of the game it's annoying to bring about a character who is totally blindsiding an target, only for that target to turn around and take a shot.  

What was the point of line of sight then?


I am also puzzled by the Advanced Wars CO powers. It would be nice to get an ingame guide or a little wording to tell you what it the powers do. Not just subject a person to the laughable scrolling character then the enemies taking damage.


Oh and Steam Cloud Sync only broke my game. Nearly completed a hard run as Marie on my Laptop. Synced it with my main computer. Beat the game, game crashes during credits, unlocked nothing. Not even Marie Stars.  So, 3 hours played while I was on vacation lost and they didn't even appear on my account. Oh well.

review:
I want to say this is like a Super Gameboy version of FTL meets Valkyria Chronicles but the execution falls way short of that. The game has a map system with your squad contantly fleeing enemy pursuit, much like FTL, and it has a kind of combination real-time and turn-based combat , much like Valkyria Chronicles, but it's rather shallow and unrewarding. 

In FTL you want to hit many nodes because you never know what reward you might walk away with. Here, though, random "do the risky thing or leave" choices are never really worth the risk and combat only rewards you meger gold that you're going to need to patch yourself up after the fight so you basically just make a bee-line for the exit using the shortest route possible..

The combat is the most disappointing, though. Much like Valkyria Chronicles, if you get close to enemies they automatically fire at you on your turn but during enemy turns your units never fire back at the enemies and they HURT. When 1 shot can put your guy down, you basically can't let the enemy have a single turn or you get wiped. 

Overall, it's not a terrible game. It just falls way, way short of it's potential. I'd rate it neutral if I could but since there's nothing really stand-out about the gameplay and I have to go with "yes" or "no", I'm going to have to lean toward "no", sadly.

review:
My initial reaction to the game was of utmost exasperation. I spent a couple of hours trying to get a grip on this sequel to what was an excellent game in my opinion. But my early hours not providing any dividends, I decided to call it quits. And so I let this game rest in my library for a very long while. But then I decided to give it another try because of the love I had for its prequel. 

I won't lie to you, this game is very different from Super Trench Attack, but once you spend some time playing it, you will realise that it is a fun game to play in its own respect. Sure this game needs some changes, but it wouldn't have been as fun had it been perfect. People can still expect the humour that was to be found in the first one. And for those who love the turn-based gameplay, this game can be an option.

Do I recommend it as much as I do the first one, probably not. But that doesn't mean people shouldn't get it. Wait for the sale and if you have a few pennies lying around, look this game up. 

I'd say a high 7 out of 10.

I would not recommand this game to my friends, especially comaring to STA1's massive success. I would like to spend 20 more hours for STA1 though it's not perfect. But for this one I would only play it for less than hour, then take the card and go away.  

It is a totally different game comparing with STA1. I can see many games in it, Oregon Trail, Valkyrie Chronicles, and Advanced War. But the problem is, it is NOT FUN anymore, and not free anymore. STA1 makes you feel like playing Skyrim WWI. You can go wherever you want, take down enemies to make some money and get lootings, complete missions, go find hidden places on the map, etc. But in STA2 you can only march in fixed routes which I dont even know what's the scenery is like, it's just lines, dots, lines, dots. Le jeux semble etre un mix entre FTL et valkyria chronicle : vous ete sur une carte avec des "point d'interet", vous vous deplacer de point en point, parfois des bataille se lance, parfois un evenement au debouchÃ©e aleatoire et parfois rien ne se passe, certain point sont des magasin et finalement le point final qui sert a passer a une autre zone, un ecran de selection des zone apparait et nous permet de choisir notre itineraire pour atteindre notre but. Si vous avez jouer a FTL vous savez exactement quoi imaginer. Le carburant de FTL est ici remplacer par de la nourriture, consommÃ©e par chaque menbre de votre ascouade et a chaque mouvement, en fonction de la quantitÃ©e de rationnement la nourriture diminue + ou - vite et il en vas de meme pour la regeneration de vos soldat a chaque mouvement ( de base chaque soldat consomme 5 point de nourriture et regenere 5% de vie).

Les combat se deroule comme valkyrie chronicle : le combat commence sur la carte du champ de bataille, la vous selectionner un de vos soldat pour pouvoir le controler : le deplacement et tirer, vous avez une jauge de deplacement et vous pouvez vous deplacer apres avoir tirer. d'autre action peuvent se faire a la place de tirer comme le tres utile kit de soin qui peut etre utiliser une fois par bataille ( si vos soldat en sont equiper bien sur), les unitÃ©es que vous placer en defense pourront tirer sur les ennemis qui se deplace dans leur champ de tir. en tuant des ennemis vos soldat gagnent de l'xp et des niveau, en montant de niveaux ils peuvent utiliser des pack d'equipement de plus haut niveaux et donc devenir plus puissant et solide. Un scout ne peut equiper qu'un pack d'equipement de scout, les pack d'equipement peuvent egalement contenir un outil tels que les grenade ou un kit de soin et peuvent egalement avoir un buff qui a malheuresement une faible de rater quand on l'active (vampirisme, bonus de degat et malus a la defense, bonus a la precision, possibilitÃ©e de faire un point de degat ou 999,....). 
J'ai rencontrer 4 classes : les scout (representÃ© par un galon) avec un tres bon deplacement, un fusil puissant et qui tire loin + un pistolet qui peut tirer 3 fois ( utile pour finir un ennemis blesser et tirer encore sur une autre cible, ou quand vous etes pret de votre cible pour essayer de faire 3 headshot).
 Le mitrailleur (representÃ© par un double galon) utilise une puissante mitrailleuse qui peut facilement tuer un ennemis d'une action, voir 2 si ils sont l'un derriere l'autre, la shotgun qui peut tirer 2 fois est tres puissante et touche tout les ennemis a proximitÃ©e.

 Le mortier ( representer par un obus) dispose d'une puissant mortier, tout simplement :)

Les packs d'equipement s'achete principalement au magasin tout comme la nourriture,des soldat suplementaire et des soin, les soldat "wounded" qui se sont fait abattre quoi, ne regenere plus de santÃ© au fil des deplacement et doivent etre soigner via un magasin, l'or se gagne surtout en bataille, avec un bonus si vous tuer vos ennemis en 1 tour. On pourrait   penser que se jeux serait facile mais en fait pas du tout : les arme sont puissante et les soldat fragile, comme dans valkyria chronicle on dispose d'une quantitÃ©e de point d'action pour faire jouer ses soldat, du coup on peut tous les utiliser sur le meme et ravager la menace a portÃ©e de ce soldat, mais l'ennemis peut faire de meme et en generale ils ne se baladent pas sans objectif : ils veulent vous faire la peau.

On se retrouve finalement avec un jeux qui peut "vite se finir" (comme FTL quoi, si on a de la chance, qu'on joue bien et le tout avec une bonne connaissance du jeux) mais qui se trouve etre un jeux plutot interessant a jouer et qui une rejouabilitÃ©e sympathique (3 personnage principal a debloquer avec 5 composition de depart a debloquer) avec 3 niveau de difficultÃ©e bien doser : vous voulez en mode facile ? le jeux vous permet de finir la plupart des combat rapidement et facilement mais avec un minimum de tension dans les grosse mission, en mode normal les chose se corsent rÃ©ellement ( puisque d'ailleur je ne l'ai pas encore fini en normal au moment ou j'ecrit ces lignes :D ). author: {'steamid': '76561198044297054', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1455617614}
review:
Super Trench Attack 2 is a blast! I see a lot of people comparing it to FTL. I guess I can see why people would make that comparison. The map looks similar, you have crazy good/bad random events, and you can hire a squad as you progress. It is a rogue-lite, like FTL, so there is permadeath. Beyond these similarities the gameplay is much different.

As you move along the map screen you will encounter combat situations that will require you to put your squad to use. You will see representations of your squad members and enemies on a battlefield layout screen. From here you can strategize the best way to take out the enemy squad within your limited amount of turns. From the layout screen you can select one of your units and the game will switch into a top-down perspective of the battlefield. You are allowed to move and shoot a limited amount each turn (pistols=3 shots, shotguns=2 shots, rifles=1 shot, etc). This makes for some fun, strategic gameplay that I didn't grow tired of at all in my initial session.

The graphics are a throwback to late 80's/early 90's pc games- I can appreciate that. The Oregon Trail inspired hunting events are also a nice touch. Finally, the music is great. In particular, the music played during enemy turns. I can definitely recommend this game strongly to anyone who enjoys a good rogue-lite or even just an awesome nostaglia trip.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079789371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1452987735}
review:
Hell, no! The first Super Trench Attack was an awesome not-to-be-taken-seriously shooter game with tons of bad guys, fun boss battles and something like a coherent story. This comes from the south end of a north-bound bull. 

We have a turn-based "strategy". You move the your squad between map points from West to East (spending your food), with each point marking a random event, a battle or a shop. A red area covers the map behind you, showing the progress of the enemy army. The reason this all happens is that you stole enemy invasion plans and need to get them home to avoid the impending war. 

If this doesn't scream FTL at you, go buy that game, it's orders of magnitude better than this shit. The main reason being that in FTL, the encounters get you better equipment, more crew and ship upgrades. Here, you get some cash, some food or some damage. Randomly. So, while in FTL you are motivated to visit as many places as you can, here your best option is to take the shortest route to the exit.

The battles themselves look like tiny X-com missions - your soldiers can move some distance per turn, shoot (1x rifle or 2x pistol) or do some other stuff. Two pistol headshot hits are not enough to kill an enemy. And I didn't fihure out how to use grenades. 

Plus, the ugly pixelated graphics. That was the only part I hated in the fist game - I know it's "retro", but it sucks. Why can't we get a simple game that looks like it's the 21st century? The hardware can handle it, the game runs at almost any resolution, so why do we keep pretending we're stuck in 1984?

review:
It's not a bad game really. The graphics are intentionally wacky and the settings are ridiculous. The system is good mix between FTL and Valkyria Chronicle, so if you are into turn base games and roguelike, chances are this game will entertain you for a while.

THAT BEING SAID, the game lacks depth. The battles, while interesting at first, becomes chore as soon as you get the hang of the game. The rogue-like depth is also pretty low as the game gets somewhat easy as soon as you figureout the effective combos. 

Balance is also terrible, as certain classes are absolutely useful while others are either somewhat limited to absolutely useless. The only classes that really shines in this game are scouts(initial class) and heavies. The other class has little justification for existence.

But at the price, is sitll enjoyable experience. I will recommend this game, but it's only a time killer at best.

review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]
While Super Trench Attack 1 was just a regular top-down shooter with crazy graphics style, the second game is absolutely different in terms of gameplay. It's obvious that the developer got inspired by two great games - FTL: Faster than Light and Valkyria Chronicles. 

Super Trench Attack 2 is a game where you proceed through randomly generated locations and battles, including special events like meeting mad men, bussinessmen, getting crew healed/damaged etc. The whole battle part is same like in mentioned Valkyria Chronicles - it's turn-based but all movement of specific characters are done directly by WASD controls.

As the previous game by this developer, graphic style is not serious but it's made in original silly way that you may like or hate. Check the screenshots and you'll see.

[h1]Positives:[/h1]
- [b]Unlockable content that motivates you to play again[/b]. More playable characters and upgrades.
- [b]RPG level and item set system for every character[/b].
- [b]Unique silly graphics[/b]. Close to pixelart, not close to seriousness at all. 
- [b]Low system requirements[/b]. 
- [b]Low price in relation to the content[/b]. 

[h1]Neutrals:[/h1]
- [b]Higher difficulty[/b]. But this is a standard for roguelike games.

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]
- [b]Repetitive battles[/b]. This guy goes there, shoots that guy. Another guy goes there, shoots any other guy...

author: {'steamid': '76561197995086922', 'num_games_owned': 1619, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1455655068}
review:
Pretty fun! Worth a look. 
I dug Super Trench Attack, more or less. This is a much different game.
Turn based, squad-based battles instead of real-time clicky action. The system is interesting. You have a certain amount of movement radius to use per squad member per turn (if you activate them), as well as a certain number of activation points you can use to make your squad members fire weapons.

You use WASD to make your active squad member move, and can only see a certain distance around them, though you can, at any time, check the map layout to see where the enemies are. Not certain why view distance is limited this way; probably to keep the sprites at an appropriate size, which is understandable. 

There are some light RPG elements to the squad building, but don't expect Jagged Alliance / XCOM / Wasteland 2 levels of customization. There are a few different classes, and you can select different weapon loadouts for particular characters. 

There are also some random events between encounters, but they more or less seem to be either ways to lose or gain HP, or ways to buy stuff slightly cheaper or trade food for money. 

That being said, I haven't played it that much yet... I will play it again, which is probably the biggest recommendation I can give.

review:
Okay, I finally got around to making a somewhat decent look on the game after the early access period and man this review was way overdue. Basically, not much has changed from when it was in early access with the exception of additional content being put into the game, with the new Company Officers being as unlockables after making a couple of runs by earning points towards unlocking them with different setups to start your journey with. However, I will be mostly be talking about the differences between Super Trench Attack 2 and another game that is clearly based off from is the gameplay aspect of Valkyria Chronicles.

What traits does each game share?

-The turn-based strategy of selecting a unit and controlling them freely around the map with a limited amount of stamina based on unit type
-The setting is based around a world war setting
-The general difficulty is your small squad vs the world

Traits that's more prevelant in Valkyria Chronicles:

-Heavily story-driven with visual novel-like cutscenes (very good story if not a bit clichÃ©)
-Third-person mode makes it easier to spot enemies from a distance once your soldiers have line-of-sight
-Soldiers in your squad has personality in some description full with voice acting and unique character models
-Somewhat varying objectives throughout the campaign
-Multiple playthroughs are discouraging due to the imbalance in power between you and the enemy (mainly you can upgrade your squad and equipment to the point where you are straight up overpowered with orders breaking the difficulty even more)
-Again, the enemy is heavliy underpowered compared to you.You can go through the entire campaign without spending a single upgrade

Traits that's more prevelant in Super Trench Attack 2:

-Gameplay is clearly the focus of Super Trench Attack 2
-Very silly atmosphere compare to Valkyria Chronicles' serious atmosphere
-Rouge-like elements with randomized battlefields
-Difficulty is unforgiving so if you are not prepared for large scale fights, good luck
-Unit controls in a top-down view so it's more difficult to spot enemies across the level, but they do give you feedback on line-of-sight and when you've entered their firing range
-Little to no character personality
-Squad size is half the size of what you can deploy in Valkyria Chronicles
-no variable objecives with the only objective available is to eliminate the enemy team (Valkyria Chronicles mostly have you capture a specific control point, but they do mix it up from time to time)

Would I recommend Super Trench Attack 2? The answer is yes, especially if you love the gameplay of Valkyria Chronicles, but are also looking for a challange that Valkyria Chronicles fail to provide after your first playthrough.

review:
Super Trench Attack 2 is a great game even at its recent launch into early access. It's different playstyle from the Original (Squad based-turn-based, rather then a top down Isometric Shooter) Gives a new playstyle which I've found to be quite enjoyable. The games small events are generally funny due to being out of proportion in a way, and the game still can prove a challenge if your not careful.

That being said, this game is a little repetitive due to it being in it's current state. Each Zone only has one map, and currently the only kind of mission is combat - Meaning it can begin to get repetitive, but im pretty sure new missions and probably maps will come out at some time sooner or later.

So yeah, from my experience, I'd give this game an 8/10 in it's current state.
Even if you don't really want this game, keep an eye on it - it has potential.
